Comment: The Exchange Variation, popularised by Bobby Fischer. White gives Black the two Bishops in exchange for a slightly better pawn formation. It might have been enough for Fischer; for mere mortals there's a whole middle game ahead...

Better than 4...bxc6. Now if White captures the e-pawn Black has 5...Qd4, regaining the pawn with a slight advantage.
Now White has supported his own e-pawn, Black's is genuinely threatened.
Fischer actually recommended 5...f6, but I thought I'd try this instead, which is perfectly playable, as is 5...Qd6.
A bit over cautious, I think. White wants to prevent the pin, but would be better completing his development.
So I can go to g6, adding to the defence of my e-pawn.
This rather creates a hole on d4. Perhaps the idea is to lure away the Bishop so the e-pawn can be taken?
I continue with the planned support of the e-pawn.
White has now made five pawn moves and he still hasn't castled or started to develop his Q-side. This should give me some advantage.
I've nearly finished developing while White is way behind.
Still preoccupied with attacking the Bishop.
I take the opportunity to try to undouble my pawns.
White obliges...
Not a bad idea, to seize the long diagonal and renew an attack on my e-pawn. But it allows me a neat tactic...
Not a bad idea, to seize the long diagonal and renew an attack on my e-pawn. But it allows me a neat tactic...
Which I miss, as preoccupied with defending the pawn as White is in attacking it; 11...Nf4 attacks the g-pawn and the d-pawn and must win one of them.
Too late now White has castled!
Too late now White has castled!
A bit of an ugly attempt to defend the d-pawn.
I see a chance to blow open White's K-side pawns...
For some reason, here I thought I'd trapped the Rook...
For some reason, here I thought I'd trapped the Rook...
Completely missing this defence.
